Dialogue: Now, who is this? Maria Filipovna.

Dialogue: You're both looking so well. Life here at Telyatinki obviously agrees with you.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: God bless you, boy. What are you nervous about, now? Sit down. Sit down.

Dialogue: Dear Masha, Valentin tells me you're the great treasure of Telyatinki. He claims you're a very gifted teacher.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: We're happy to have you with us.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: You've killed a living thing.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Do you have something to say?

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: It's absurd. That's all.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: What are you saying?

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I'm sorry but- It's a mosquito.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Forgive him. He can't help it. He's a better Tolstoyan than I am.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: It's not the message we want to send.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: From my mother "Nerves dreadful. Stop. Insomnia. Stop. Pulse 100. Stop. Please come home.

Dialogue: Don't give in to her, Papa. It'll never end...I swear to God, that woman has an instinct for knowing when you're just about to enjoy yourself

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: From Sofya Andreyevna. "I beg you. Stop. Unwell. Stop. Hurry back."

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Who taught her to use that damned machine?

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Perhaps Sasha's right. Encouraging this may not be the best thing.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: It's a trick, Papa. She'll drain you. You'll be miserable.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Then, let me go with you.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: No, my dear, I'll go alone.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Sofya.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Sofya, are you ill?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: I'm fine...now that you're home.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: It's no good, you know, all this. You frightened everyone.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Did I really? I don't believe it. Not you. I'm your little bird. You know the sounds I make.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: That was some sort of love call?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: It brought you back to me.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Come out of the dark... where I can see you.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Why? Why? Why, do you do it? We live in the country and you insist on making it an opera house. What's wrong with a little peace now and then?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Look at me. This is who I am. This is what you married. We're older, maybe we're old, but I'm still your little chicken  You're still my big cock.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Let me make you crow.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Let me make you sing.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Do you love me?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: I want you to love me.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I'm not supposed to do this either.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Masha. You are not supposed to smoke at Telyatinki.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: You wouldn't look at me.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: It was difficult in front of the others.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: But it wasn't difficult in your bed... When it was only you and me in front of God.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I'm not sure I was conscious of God.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: So, I made you forget God?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: Yes, only for a moment. You forgot your rules and remembered love.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: You make it sound very simple.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: It is simple. What we did is what men and women do, have done, will continue doing. What could be more simple? We touched each other-- stayed close together. Something passed between us. Something real. That is a betrayal of what? Of nothing.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I'm afraid I've hurt you, havent I?

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: No. I feel a little sad, but it is not for me. It's for you.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Good morning, my darling? Do you mind if I join you?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Of course, my dear.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: It's quite insane, my darling. Everyone is making fun of you.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: What are you talking about?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Even the muzhiks. I heard them laughing in the barn.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Laughing about what?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: I don't want to ruin last night.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Laughing about the fact that you've developed a senile crush on a fat middle aged flatterer. Your passion for Chertkov has become a standing joke.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I have a great affection for Vladimir Grigorivich. Let them laugh if they find it amusing.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: But it's not amusing, darling. It's sick. It's not normal. You hang on his every word.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: We have a great deal in common.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: You have nothing in common. You are a genius. He's a sycophant and a pervert.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Because he understands what I'm trying to do? Because he tries to help me accomplish it?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: He is using you. You just can't seem to see it.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: This is absolute nonsense.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: That bold, obese, idiotic man. You treat him...

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: It's impossible for you not to distract me. Let me alone... for God's sake. You're like a spoiled child.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Do you love me, Lyovochka?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Of course, I do.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Then why would you betray me?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Why do you say that?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Because of the will?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: The new will.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: There's no new will.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: There is no new will.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Does Chertkov have it?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: There's no new will.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: But that's why he's come back. You talk about it, you and your boyfriend. You plan for it. You have no heart for the people who really love you. You'd rather be seduced by charlatans and deluded by flatterers, all in the name of love....You can't even love your own children. You can't even love me.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Tell me where it is?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: There is no new will.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Then, promise me there never will be.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Ive told you the truth. Now, let me work. Please, will you?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Tomorrow, I'll go to the Station and lie down on the track. Tolstoy's wife becomes Anna Karenina herself! See how the papers will like that!

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: She's here to question you about the new will.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: How does she know it even exists?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: She claims Leo Nikolayevich told her she could examine the draft.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: He is obviously not thinking clearly. And now we have to put up with her petty grasping.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: It doesn't seem petty to me.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: I beg your pardon?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: He`s her life. The work, in her mind, is theirs...together.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: And you're her advocate? You've been taken in by her celebrity. I worried about this.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I'm talking about their history -- - simply that.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: We should see her. Act as if nothing has happened.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Nothing has happened.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Sofya Andreyevna, at last, you honour us with your visit.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: And I'm happy to make you happy...always.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Your moustache is...

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: It's a problem of the wax.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Let me get to the point. Vladimir Grigorivich, I don't wish to be your enemy. I'm delighted that my husband has a friend who understands and shares his ideals. All I want is what's reasonable - an opportunity to evaluate the new will. If you agree, I'm sure we can be friends.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: You're very kind. Sofya Andreyevna. But I can't help you. Not without specific instructions from your husband.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Leo Nikolayevich has agreed, hasn't he Val-

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: No witness you produce will change my position. But I'll certainly talk to Leo Nikolayevich at the first opportunity.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Very well.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: I want us to be friends, too, Sofya. Leo Nikolayevich is the most valuable thing in the world, for both of us. We should endeavor to set things right between us. Give him peace. Let him work.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Yes.  Valentin Fedorovich...are you coming back to the house with me?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I'll escort the Countess home and be back in time for supper.

Speaker: sergeyenko
Dialogue: Masha will be overjoyed.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: We've become close friends, I think. Tell me everything, dear boy. I love a romance.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: It's nothing, really.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: A young woman in your life is nothing?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Masha is a friend.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: A lover?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: A good friend.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: That sounds serious enough.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: I don't mean to annoy you.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I'm not annoyed.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: You forget that I'm an experienced reader. I can read your face, every letter. It's beautifully clear.  Do you love her?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Maybe I do.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Not something they'd understand, these so called disciples of my husband. They've never understood a word he's written.  What do any of them know about love?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Sorry, sorry, I'll... I didn't mean to scare you...Are you alright.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: Fine...fine...Why did you...?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I came back as soon as I could. It was a strange day. Leo Nikolayevich,...I love to listen to him. I love nothing more...

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: But today I could hardly concentrate.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: All I could think of was you.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I think I've confused you. I've confused us both.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: No. No. You didnt confuse me..I was stupid. I was afraid, but I'm not afraid anymore.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I love you, Masha!

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: Maybe you could help me a little.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Masha...

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Before the other night...I'd committed the act of copulation many times in my heart.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: Yes...

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I think about you all the time. In my heart Ive comitted the act of copulation many times. I just want to say...It was never like it was with you.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I'll wait for you, then.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Ivan, who's wearing that awful perfume?

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: I hate to say it but the Countess has become more and more dangerous.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Not dangerous... She's concerned for the welfare of the family.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Take this down.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Its a terrible thing you ask. I cant do it.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: You've been more than reasonable. She already controls the income from your property.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Listen to him, papa. He has our best interests at heart.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: We're speaking only of the rights to your words, your ideas.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: She's my wife. Shes part of me. We've been together now, so many years....

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: But you're more than a husband and father. She must understand that. The best interests of the people are one with your own. You belong to them.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: She's unstable...I wonder if she isn't ill.

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: Its sadly more than possible.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: I know its hard for you, papa. But we must be realistic.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: How dare you?

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: You're all plotting against me. In my own house, too. I bear you thirteen children. How can you betray me like this?  Someone help me up.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Give everything you've got to him, your fat little catamite. "What will it be, my dearest dear, my Vladimir Grigorivich? My wife's heart on a platter? Her kidneys? With salt? But of course, my dear Chertkov, whatever pleases you. The china. The estate. Permanent copyright on everything I've ever written? Anything for you, my love."

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Give me that. Give it to me, you little weasel.

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: Please, Countess Sofya-

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Mama, please...

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Now...

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Can I not...Can I not have...

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: You'll kill him, Mama. That's what you want, isn't it? You want him to die!"

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: You! Don't think you deceive me for one little moment! I know exactly what you're doing. I want to see the will. It's my right, in the name of god.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: What are you afraid of?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: You.   I'm afraid of you.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: The press is bloodthirsty. Had I wished, I could've demolished you and your family. You make it easy.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Tell them anything you like. Go ahead. Ruin us.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: I have too much respect for Leo Nikolayevich. You're lucky.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Why can't my husband see you for what you are?

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: If I had a wife like you, I would have blown my brains out long ago.  Or gone to America.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I hope you're feeling better.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Do you like the opera?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I took singing lessons for years. I thought about a career in music. The only thing I lacked, in the end, was talent.  I'm sorry about everything.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: This aria is very beautiful.. It is about a woman who is abandoned by the man who loves her...Everyone is very moved by that...in the opera.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Our life together has become intolerable.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Sit down, Valentin.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Really, I'm expected at Telyatinki.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: No, no, no. Enjoy your dinner. We've had a disagreement. No more than any other married couple.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I didn't come for more recrimination. Despite good cause for alienation between us, I have never stopped loving you.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Of course...

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: God knows you don't make it easy.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Why should it be easy? I'm the work of your life. You're the work of mine. Its what love is.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Everything with him is hysterics

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I should go.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Sit down.  So, this is what love is.   Does that surprise you, boy?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I thought it might be quieter, but-

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: He's right, though. If we cannot live a decent, quiet life, if I cannot work, if I cannot find some peace, I shall simply go away.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Go? Where?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Not to Chertkov, but I shall go.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Go where?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Dushan says you're killing me.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Then go! Go! Anywhere you please!

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: I hate you. I hate what you've become.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Countess...Are you alright?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: DUSHAN!!!

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: You'll destroy me.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Is she alright?

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: Sofya! Open your eyes.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: My back. My back... I'm hurting.

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: You're lying on a fork. Sit up and you'll improve markedly...Valentin, help to get her upstairs, would you?

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: She's alright. I'm more concerned for you... We should all go to bed before something else happens.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: It was terrible there today... between them. They loved each other so much, but you see what it becomes.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Masha, whats the matter?

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I'm going back to Moscow.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: Chertkov spoke with me this afternoon. He says I could be more useful there...which means...

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: This is him punishing us, punishing me for befriending Sofya Andreyevna. For not... This is Chertkov.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: We've both disappointed him.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I don't care. You can't go away. I'll talk to him. I'll make him change his mind. im going to make you stay.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: No, I want to go.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I'm leaving the movement.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: You cant leave Tolstoy.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I am not. Look, when I read his Confession, it moved me, Valya. He was searching for freedom. Freedom from anger. Freedom from attachment. Freedom from all the superstition and nonsense of the church. It moved me so much. I thought that's what it would be about. Isn't that what it's about? Freedom and love? But they mix it all up.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: Come with me. Please.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I'm going to my room.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Don't leave me, Masha... I need you.

Speaker: masha
Dialogue: I know you do...I know.

Speaker: rossolimo
Dialogue: I believe the Countess suffers from a mental degeneracy, paranoic and hysterical, chiefly the former.

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Why did you bring him here?

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: He's an old friend, you know, from Rome.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: And astoundingly stupid in the way of all scientists.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I'm sorry, my friend, but this is all very upsetting to me.

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Take them downstairs. Thank them for me. Offer them a drink.

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: You'll be alright?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Valentin Fedorovich will stay with me, won't you, boy

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Ya...your...your...I cant remember now...Yo, what did I say? What did you mean?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: You rest now.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: You see, I no longer feel I have a choice in the matter. She isn't...

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Good afternoon, Leo Nikolayevich.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Is it?

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: This will insure that the complete works will live in the public domain.

Speaker: sergeyenko
Dialogue: Monumentous.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Your work is the birthright of the Russian people. Now, they possess it forever.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I need a pen.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: You're a secretary.       How can you not have a pen?

Speaker: sergeyenko
Dialogue: He's a secretary, too.      Ask him.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Valentin Fedorovich, do you have a pen?

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Are you alright?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I feel like a conspirator.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Maybe we should get back. It'll be dark soon. May I ask you something that has nothing to do with work?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Of course, my dear.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Do you love your wife?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: " Your youth and your desire for happiness reminds me cruelly of my age and the impossibility of happiness for me." When I was courting Sofya, she was so young and pure, it seemed impossible that I'd ever have her. I didn't want to tell her how I felt and I wanted to tell her nothing else. So I wrote down a string of letters and asked her if she could decipher them. She looked completely confused, thinking it was a game or...

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I gave her one clue. The first two Y's, I said, stand for "your youth" and then the most miraculous thing happened. She simply spoke the phrase, my phrase...

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: ...as if she had read my mind. In that moment, we both knew we would always be together. For those first years, we were incredibly happy, terrifyingly happy.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: And now this.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Thank you again, Valentin Fedorovich, for your forethought.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I'm a secretary, after all.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: You know I had thought for a time to suggest that Leo Nikolayevich look for someone else. But...he said no. He said "He reminds me of myself when I was young."

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I'm leaving Telyatinki.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Really.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I am going to Moscow.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: She is leading you around the nose.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Look, you say the movement's about love-

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Yes... The love he tells us to practice, the love of the Gospels. Why do I have to explain this? Perfect love. Eternal love. The love that binds mankind together.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: But I've never met mankind, only men and women, imperfect men, imperfect women.

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Leo Nikolayevich also teaches us love can not be weakminded. Go. You won't be missed ...a naive sentimentalist

Speaker: chertkov
Dialogue: Why are you laughing? You think I'm ridiculous.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I'm laughing because I didn't sneeze.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Lyovochka? Prozeveskeny wants to purchase the rights to your work after your death.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Then I shall try and die as soon as is convenient.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Don't be silly. They've offered one million rubles.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: How can you not be pleased?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I don't write for publishers. I write for people.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Valentin's in the library.    He's asked to speak to me.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: Splendid...while your wretched family is left to starve.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I don't see anyone starving in this house. On the contrary, our privilege revolts me.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: But you're always first to the trough...always have been.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: What is it, dear boy? You look unhappy. What do you want to say?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Sofya, what are you doing?

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: How could you do this to me?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: You're not well.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: You hurt me again and again. You take little pieces of me until I become nothing. I don't know who I am anymore.  I read your diary. I know what you've done.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: You behave like this, I have no choice. Now give me the gun.

Speaker: sofya
Dialogue: No! Give me the gun!

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Give it to me, please.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I'd like you to stay here tonight.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Yes, of course.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Get up. He's leaving.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Hes leaving.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Essentials only. Nothing that isn't absolutely necessary.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Please...we must hurry.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Where will you go?

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Absolutely essential.

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: A lantern, I think. It's very dark tonight.  And the apparatus for giving an enema.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Everything's ready.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Papa...?

Speaker: dushan
Dialogue: He's changed his mind. He's going back to the house.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: Do you want to go back?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: When I was a boy, my brother Nikolai once brought me to a place when I was a boy. He told me he'd found a green stick with some words on it... the secret to happiness for all men everywhere. He hid it in the ground. I looked for it very often. I've looked for it all these years. I really believed I would find it here...but I never did.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: I never did...but this life is behind me now.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Help me up, will you?

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Give this to Sofya.

Speaker: valentin
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: sasha
Dialogue: Be well. Be well.

Speaker: tolstoy
Dialogue: Don't cry. I'll send for you when I can.

Dialogue: I'm simply telling you what happened. He's gone. I have no idea where. Nobody does.
